title-group.article-title: ELIZA AND RITA, PAUL AND LUKE: THE ECLIPSE AND KENOSIS OF INTEGRITY IN "PYGMALION, EDUCATING RITA", AND "SIX DEGREES OF SEPARATION"

Jeffrey Hopkins objects to views of "absolute emptiness" applied to Tibetan Bud- dhism, in Meditation on Emptiness (1983; Boston: Wisdom Publications, 1996), 16.

Schubert Ogden's criticisms of Masao Abe's relating Christian kenosis to Kyoto school Buddhist views of sunyata (emptiness, nothingness), in The Emptying God: A Buddhist-Jewish- Christian Conversation, ed. John Cobb,Jr. and Christopher Ives (Mary Knoll: Orbis, 1990), 125-34.

Janet Gyatso cautions against absolute emptiness in "Compassion at the Millen- nium: A Buddhist Salvo for the Ethics of the Apocalypse," in Lissa McCullough and Brian Schroeder, eds., Thinking Through the Death of God: A Critical Companion to Thomas J. J. Altizer (New York: SUNY , 2004), 147-67.
Catherine Keller expresses similar reservations in her response to Abe, in Cobb and Ives, eds., 102-115.
Marta Frascati-Lochhead analyzes several Feminist appropriations of kenosis in Kenosis and Feminist Theology: The Challenge of Gianni Vattimo (New York: SUNY, 1998).
